body.p:
Stanford, Kentucky
15th December 1865
Governor T, E, Bramlett,
My Dear Sir

About Twelve months Since a Young Man in his Eighteenth year from Texas and formerly a Confederate Soldier -- stole from my Lot in stanford a sorrel mare, saddle & bridal, rode her about one mile and was met by one of my sons & brothersinlaw who arrested him brought back the prisonr tried him before Court of Inquiry, by which he was sent to further trial, and at the March Term of our court, he was indicted by the Grand Jury for horse stealing the cause continued and the boy still remains in prison -- He is young and been well raised and is of good appearance and well Educated has been in confinement in our county Jail
for about one year, is entirely destitute of clothes and is in miserable condition to pass the coming winter in our prison house of stone and iron; after considering the matter maturely, Looking at the Extreme Youth of the prisoner, his Long confinement in our County Jail which of itself has been a great punishment, to the fact that this is a time of almost universal pardon, at the miserable condition of this poor boy I have felt it my duty to ask your Excellecy to pardon said boy -- I feel that he has been sufficiently punished, that he may suffer greatly in prison this winter, that humanity, the youth and good appearance of said boy requires his pardon -- I feel confident that under the circumstances the enlightened public sentiment of the County will sustain you in granting the pardon I ask for said boy -- I therefore pray your Excellcy will speedily pardon said prisoner whose name is George
Adams -- Hoping to hear speedily from your Excellecy favourably I remaine

Your Obdent Servant
Wm A. Pollock

Governor T, E, Bramlette
Dear Sir
The undersigned Citizens of Stanford and viciinty Know the facts stated by our neighbor W A Pollock true we therefore concur in the pryer of his petition for the parden of George Adams

Respectfully
W. S.
Saml H Shanks
Thos H Shanks
Ed. Davidson
J, R, Alford
W,, R,, Carson J P L C
M. V. Smith
W. R. Warren
A. J. C. Robbins
